_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CAROLINA COLD STORAGE ( CCS )

Risk Management Program

Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy



CCS has a Process Safety Management Program (PSM ) to identify, evaluate, and prevent chemical releases that could occur due to a failure in process, procedures, or equipment.



The PSM is designed to provide reasonable assurance that operational hazards are identified, that significant operational safety incidents are avoided, that operational safety requirements are considered in evaluating decisions and that risks to persons, property, products, and the environment are minimized or avoided.



The PSM program includes all phases of plant operations including conceptualization, design, construction, operation, maintenance, and decommissioning. The program in place covers all aspects of OSHA's CFR 1910.



CCS has a program for employees covering lockout tag-out and Personnel Protective Clothing (PPE), PPE testing emergency response training, and confined space training. Yearly inspections are performed on all aspects of the process.



Facility Description and Regulated Substance



CCS is a refrigerated warehouse that uses anhydrous ammonia for the refrigerant. It is located on Highway 87 North, Tar Heel, NC 28392. The warehouse, which was built in 1992, is a 179,000 square foot facility designed to freeze and store frozen commodities. 



The ammonia refrigeration system is a two stage recirculated system. It utilizes a roof top evaporative condenser.



Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



The worst case scenario is the high-pressure receiver, which can hold up to 10741 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. If this vessel was damaged and all 10741 pounds released over a 10 minute period (the required assumption by the Risk Management Program parameters), 200 PPM could reach 1.80 miles from the release point as calculated by the OCA Guidance Analysis. The liquid is contained in the Machine Room. There is no passive mitig

ation system to mitigate the release of gas.



An Alternate Release Scenario, which is more likely, would be a pipe leak that could leak approximately 150 pounds of anhydrous ammonia within a 10-minute period. A toxic endpoint level of 200 PPM is 0.08 miles from the release point as calculated by the OCA Guidance Analysis. There are no residences that will be affected by the alternative release.



The facility was designed so that material-handling equipment would not be able to accidentally damage ammonia piping. The facility is controlled by a computer system that can assist in reducing the quantity of ammonia released. The computer system can be controlled from off-site also.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The engineers have been trained to follow the PSM program guidelines established for this facility. Employees participate in regular safety meetings, safety inspections, and annual training classes on ammonia safety.



A preventative maintenance program and facility check lists provide routine inspection of the refrigeration system. An annual inspection following the International Association of Refrigerated Warehouses (IIAR) guidelines is performed on the equipment. The facility design incorporated good safety practices for ammonia refrigeration.



5 Year Accident History



 There have been no accidental releases at this facility. 



Emergency Response Program



The Emergency Response Program includes coordination with the County of Bladen Office of Emergency Services.



The facility engineers have received the 24 hour Emergency Responder Training and receive an annual 8 hour Responder Refresher Course.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



CCS plans to improve its safety program in several ways. A program has been put into place to evaluate the Process Safety Management Program annually. A training program has been put in place to inform and provide additional information to employees about company safety programs. Our insurance company

provides regular inspections of our equipment. Infrared scans of all electrical switch gear and fire protection systems are performed semi-annually.



The facility has been designed and constructed in accordance with current good safety practices and procedures. There are no facility modifications pending.
